chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect syphilis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Syphilis can present with a wide range of nonspecific symptoms — in some people infection may be asymptomatic. As a result diagnosis can be delayed or missed.
  • Suspect syphilis if there is a history or presence of any of the following, especially if there are any risk factors: 
    • Genital lesion(s) — the characteristic feature of primary syphilis is a solitary, painless, indurated, genital ulcer (chancre) with a clean base and sharp border.
      • Lesions may present atypically and be painful, multiple, or extra-genital.
      • Associated regional lymphadenopathy is common.
    • A non-pruritic maculopapular rash — rash typically involves the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.
    • Moist wart-like lesions (condylomata lata) — usually develop at sites of skin friction such as perianal and vulval regions, under the breasts, and axillae.
    • Patchy lesions on the oral mucosa (‘snail tract’ lesions).
    • Generalized lymphadenopathy.
    • Unexplained neurological or ophthalmological symptoms.
  • The presence of:
    • Chancre may indicate primary syphilis — for more information, see the section on primary syphilis. 
    • A maculopapular rash, condylomata lata, oral lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, unexplained neurological or ophthalmological symptoms may indicate secondary syphilis — for more information, see the section on secondary syphilis. 
  • Tertiary syphilis rarely presents in primary care — this may be partly due to widespread use of treponemicidal antibiotics for other infections.
    • Clinical features of tertiary syphilis are varied, non-specific and can include cardiovascular, neurological, ocular and cutaneous symptoms and signs — for more information see the section on Tertiary syphilis.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlStringContent:
​​​​​​Table 1: Clinical features of primary syphilis

Timing

Clinical features (any or several may be present)

Onset: 9–90 days after exposure (mean 21 days)

 

Resolution: usually resolves spontaneously over 3–10 weeks

Chancre

  • Solitary, painless, indurated ulcer with a clean base and well defined margin (chancre) at original site of inoculation.
  • Chancre develops from a single papule or plaque.
  • Usually genital but may be extra-genital (anal, rectal, oral or on the hands).
  • May go unnoticed if painless and not visible (for example rectal).
  • Can be multiple, painful and/or purulent — multiple lesions or atypical features may be present in HIV co-infection.

Lymphadenopathy

  • Chancre may be associated with local lymphadenopathy — this may be subtle.

Data from: [Lazaro, 2013; Clement, 2014; Kingston, 2016; Nyatsanza, 2016; Watts, 2016; WHO, 2016]  [New Zealand Sexual Health Society, 2017; Peeling, 2017; BASHH, 2019; O’Byrne, 2019; ECDC, 2019; New York City Department of Health and New York City STD Prevention Training Center, 2019; PHE, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Secondary syphilis
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Table 2: Clinical features of secondary syphilis

Timing

Clinical features (any or several may be present)

Onset: 4–12 weeks after appearance of initial chancre

 

Resolution: untreated symptoms slowly resolve over 3–12 weeks but may recur (approximately 25% of cases).

 

 

Systemic features

  • Fever.
  • Malaise.
  • Headache.
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy.
  • Hepatitis.
  • Splenomegaly.
  • Glomerulonephritis.

Skin lesions

  • Skin involvement occurs in around 90% of cases.
  • Rash – usually non-pruritic, maculopapular and generalized (may only affect soles and palms).
  • Condylomata lata – grey/white moist warty lesions most commonly on oral/genital mucosa or perianal area.
  • Atypical presentations are more common in HIV co-infection.

Alopecia

  • Patchy hair loss of the scalp, beard and eyebrows.

Mucous patches

  • Oval, shallow, ulcerative patches with raised silver borders sometimes known as ‘snail tract’ ulcers.
  • May develop on oral or genital mucosa.

Early neurosyphilis

  • Occurs in a small number of people (1–2%).
  • Meningitis.
  • Cranial nerve palsies (in particular II and VIII).
  • Hearing loss.
  • Ocular disease including optic neuropathy, uveitis and retinitis.
  • Infectious arteritis (ischaemia, thrombosis, infarction).
  • People with HIV co-infection may be at increased risk of neurological complications and ocular syphilis.

Data from: [Lazaro, 2013; Clement, 2014; Kingston, 2016; Nyatsanza, 2016; Watts, 2016; WHO, 2016]  [New Zealand Sexual Health Society, 2017; Peeling, 2017; BASHH, 2019; O’Byrne, 2019; ECDC, 2019; New York City Department of Health and New York City STD Prevention Training Center, 2019; PHE, 2019]

Table 3: Clinical feature of latent syphilis

TimingClinical features

Early latent syphilis – less than 2 years duration from initial infection.

 

Late latent syphilis – more than 2 years duration from initial infection.

Asymptomatic

  • Serological evidence of infection in the absence of clinical features.
  • Around 25% of people have a recurrence of secondary disease during the early latent stage.

Data from: [Lazaro, 2013; Clement, 2014; Kingston, 2016; Nyatsanza, 2016; Watts, 2016; WHO, 2016]  [New Zealand Sexual Health Society, 2017; Peeling, 2017; BASHH, 2019; O’Byrne, 2019; ECDC, 2019; New York City Department of Health and New York City STD Prevention Training Center, 2019; PHE, 2019]

Table 4: Clinical features of tertiary syphilis

Timing

Clinical features (any or several may be present)

15 to 40 years after initial infection

Gummatous syphilis

  • Gumma — granulomatous lesions with a necrotic centre.
  • Can develop anywhere but most often affect skin and bone.

Cardiovascular syphilis

  • Cardiovascular disease — often due to vasculitis and chronic inflammation of the aortic vasa vasorum.
  • Aortic regurgitation.
  • Aortic aneurysm.
  • Heart failure.
  • Angina.

Neurosyphilis

  • Tabes dorsalis (inflammation of spinal dorsal column/nerve roots) — may present with ‘lightening pains’, paraesthesia, Charcot’s joints, pupillary change, absent reflexes, joint position and vibration sense. 
  • General paresis (cortical neuronal loss) — may present with forgetfulness and personality change which develop into severe dementia. Seizures and hemiparesis may occur.

Data from: [Lazaro, 2013; Clement, 2014; Kingston, 2016; Nyatsanza, 2016; Watts, 2016; WHO, 2016]  [New Zealand Sexual Health Society, 2017; Peeling, 2017; BASHH, 2019; O’Byrne, 2019; ECDC, 2019; New York City Department of Health and New York City STD Prevention Training Center, 2019; PHE, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the clinical features of syphilis are based on clinical guidelines Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [Lazaro, 2013], UK national guidelines on the management of syphilis 2015 [Kingston, 2016], WHO guidelines for the treatment of Treponema pallidum (syphilis) [WHO, 2016] and Syphilis. Management summary [New Zealand Sexual Health Society, 2017], UK national guidelines on the management of syphilis [BASHH, 2019], the reports Syphilis and congenital syphilis in Europe. A review of epidemiological trends (2007-2018) and options for response [ECDC, 2019] and Addressing the increase in syphilis in England: PHE Action Plan [PHE, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles [Clement, 2014; Nyatsanza, 2016; Watts, 2016; Peeling, 2017; O’Byrne, 2019; New York City Department of Health and New York City STD Prevention Training Center, 2019]. 

  • It is widely agreed that diagnosis of syphilis can be easily delayed or missed as presentation of both early and late syphilis is highly variable, non-specific and clinical features can be subtle [Peeling, 2017; Thakrar, 2018; PHE, 2019]. 
    • In addition, the chancre of primary syphilis can develop on sites which are not visible (for example, the rectum) and if painless, missed [IUSTI, 2014; WHO, 2016]  [O’Byrne, 2019; ECDC, 2019]. 
  • Co-infection with HIV does not lead to more severe early syphilis symptoms however, atypical presentations are more common [BASHH, 2019; ECDC, 2019]. 
    • Co-infection with HIV may predispose to neuro-ophthalmological complications [Peeling, 2017].
